div.p:
1
ANON.

"For many centuries after (afte) Britain became an island" the
says "#"the untamed forest was king. Its moist
and mossy floor was hidden from Heavens eye by a close drawn
curtain woven of innumerable tree tops." On those matted
boughs innumerable birds sang; but their song was only heard
by a few skin clad hunters in the clearings (lcearings). Did the desire
to sing come to one of those huntsmen because he heard the
birds sing, and so rested his axe against the tree for a
moment? But the tree had to be felled; and a hut made
from its branches before the human voice sang too.

By a bank as I lay
Musing myself alone, hey ho!
A birdes voice
Did me rejoice,
Singing before the day
And me thought in her lay
She said, winter was past, hey ho!

The voice that broke the silence (sielnce) of the forests was
the voice of . Some one heard the song and remembered (re embered) it
for it was later written (wrteen) down, beautifully on parchment.
Thus the singer had his audience, but the audience was so
little interested in his name that he never thought to give
it. For Tthe audience was itself the singer; Terly terlow"
they sand; and "By, by lullay" filling in the pauses,
helping out with a chorus. Every body shared in the emotion
of Anons song, and supplied the story. Anon sang because
spring has come; or winter is gone; because he loves; because
he is hungry, or lustful; or merry. or because he adores
some God. Anon is sometimes man; sometimes woman. He is the

common voice singing out of doors, He has no house. He lives (l ves)
a roaming (r ming) life crossing the fields, mounting the hills,
lying under the hawthown to listen to the nightingale (nightigale).

By shutting out a chimney or a factory we can still
see what saw-- the bird haunted reed whispering fen,
the down and the green scare never quite not yet healed along which
he came when he made his journeys. He was a simple singer,
lifting a song or a story from other peoples lips and letting (lettig)
the audience join in the chorus. Sometimes (Somemimes) he made a few lines
that exactly matched his emotion--
but there is no name name (mae) to that song.

Then when the houses had come together in some
clearing (lcearing) in a ring and roads, often flooded, often deep in
mud, led from hxxxx the cottage to the Manor, from the Manor
to the Church in the middle, along the roads came minstrels (minstersl) came
jugglers, bear leaders, singing their songs at the back door
to the farm hands and the maid servants in the uncouth
jargon of their native tongue.

Icham for woing al forwake
Wery no water in wore

Up stairs they spoke French. Anons words were as
uncouth to the master and mistress as to us. Anon
singing at the (yhe) back door was despised (despsied). He had no name;
he had no place, yet even if they felt contempt for the
singer whose body took its [small?] part in the [dance?] man who made songs, they tolerated him. Even Kings and Queens

the scholar tell us, must have their minstrel (misntre). They must
have They needed his comment, his buffoonery. his [uncouth?] at [illeg.] They kept him
in the [illeg.] being, tolerating (tolerting) him (h m), as we tolerate those who say out
loud what we feel but are too proud to admit. He used the
outsiders privilege to co mock the solemn (solmen), to comment upon
the established. The church men hxmxmxmxmxmxmxxx feared
and hated hating the the anonymous (anonymo s) singer. They did their best to [illeg.]
If they could, they pressed him and his [illeg.] actors gift into
the service of the church. He was to be found acting the
Mass in the church; but [illeg.] as he acted more and more his own
art, he left the church, and staged his pageant in the
churchyard, or later was given a pitch for his drama in the
market place. Still he remained nameless, often ribald,
often obscene.

Yet During the silent centuries (centruies) before the book was printed
his was the only voice to be heard in England.
Save for singing his song at the (yhe) back door the English
might be a dumb race, a race of merchants, soldiers, priests (preists);
who left behind them stones houses, cultivated fields and
great churches, but no words. He it wasIt was he who gave voice to
the old stories, who incidted the peasants when he came to
the back door to put off their working clothes and deck them
selves in green leaves. He it was who found words for them
to sing, and when ( shen) they went at the great seasons to do
homage (himage) to the old pagan Gods. He wxxxxxxxx taught them
the songs the sung at Christmas and at midsummer. He
led them to the haunted tree; to the well; to the old
burial place where they did homage (himage) to the pagan gods.
If we could see the village as it was before time

we should see tracks across the fields joining (joing) manor house to
hovel, and hovel to church. Some of those paths of course
were worn by soldiers (soliders) and labourers (labouerers). They must fight to
gather (gether) and plough together if they were not to be conquered
by man and by nature. That connection isxx as time goes on
and the [he? her?] me records the daily struggleclasses separate themselves, is still painfully
recorded in old letter books and ledgers. It makes the
staple of the old correspondence (corresp ondence) between the
of and the and of .
But there was also the the other less visible connection
--the common belief. That track between the houses in the
village has been grown over;- like the track along which the
rode to .--no one rides that way now.
But before time thxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
it was trod daily. which It led the peasants to the tree
to the well. In spring it led to the Maypole, where they
danced and sung Anons song. At Midsummer they lit the bon
fire (fir) on the hill. At Christmas the mummers acted the old
Anons old play; and the boys came singing his wassailing
song. The road led to the old graves, to the stones where
in time past the English had done sacrifice. The peasants (peasnts),
led by anon, still went that way by instinct, in spring
and summer and winter. The old Gods lay hidden beneath the
new. It was to them led by Anon that they did worship,
in their coats of green leaves, bearing swords in their hands
dancing through the houses, enacting their ancient parts.

It was the in 1477 that k finally was to kill
Anon. but it was the press also that preserved him. When

in 1477 printed the twenty one
he fixed the voice of Anon for ever. There we tap
the reservoir of common belief that lay deep sunk in the
minds of (od) peasants and nobles. There in pages
we hear the voice of Anon murmuring still. Hexxxxxx
If Caxton himself doubted--- he objected
never lived-- there were still nobles and gentry who
xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx were positive. They said that
you could (soulc) see skull at ; and the
at ; and "in other places sword and
many other things." So printed the old dream.
It is still half fact. [illeg.] It is a [buried?] world There (Ythere) is ; and ; and
; there is the and
. But real places are set in a dream world.
The roads (raods) lead past CxmxmxxuLondon to castles where Knights (Kinghts)
lie enchanted (enchannted); down the roads (rodas) ride Queens on white mules;
turns (truns) herself to stone; and a hand rises from
a lake holding . The [illeg.] It has a childs implicit belief. in the [story?]
It has a childs love of particularity. Txxxxxxxx Everything
is stated. The beauty is in the statement, not in the
suggestion. "So he went in and searched from chamber to
chamber, and found his bed, but she was not there; then Balin
looked into a little garden, and under a laurel tree
he saw her lie upon a quilt of green samite and a knight with her, and under their heads (hedads) grass and herbs". The world is
seen without comment; and did the writer know what beauty he
makes us see?

p.sup:
it brought to
the surface
the old
hidden
world

div.p:
But, save that self consciousness had not yet (hyet)
raised its mirror, the men and women are ourselves, seen

out of perspective, xxx elongated, foreshortened, but
very old, with a knowledge of all good and
all evil (allevil). They are already corrupt in this
fresh world. They have evil dreams. is doomed; the
Queens are lustful (luftful). There never was, it seems, a time
when men and women were without memory; were innocent
There never (enver) was a young world. There Bbehind the English
lay ages of toil and love. This (T is) That is the world beneath our
consciousness; the anonymous (anoymous) world to which (whcich) we can still
return (re urn). Of the writer nothing is known. The scholar can find something. But Malory is not
distinct from his book. The voice is still the voice of
. murmuring [illeg.] about Kings and Queens who are base and
heroic; vile and gentle, like ourselves (ourslves), stripped of the
encumbrances that time has wrapped about us.

But printing press foretold (foreold) the end of that
anonymous (anoyl s) world; it is now written down; fixed; nothing will
be added; even if the legend still murmurs on, and still
down in the peasants (peants) remember (rmember) how " on the night
of the full moon King Arthur and his men ride round the
hill, and their horses are shod with silver." After
that the audience became separate from the singer; After thatFor a time we
we hxxxx find someone who looks back, who gathers
together a chronicle (chornicle) of what has happened. We find the
individual, emerging from the past; His name his ;
he has a library; he owns a mastiff and digs up coins. is
dead when we meet with him. The have gone
their way. He sees the past against a back ground of the
present (presn t), and the present looks raw, degenerate against

p.sup:
But The
printed book
brought into existence
the man who can
read the man who
becomes
conscious, of the
present, of
himself, against
the background
of the past.
it brings into being the
whole, the audience—
a man like it.

div.p:
against the past. There is too much comfort now; too many
xmxmxx the pillow has taken the place of the old log with
a dip in the middle; there are too many chimneys (chimenys). The young
and are not the men their fathers were.
They are tender and subject to rheumatism. Also
they dress most fantastically (fantasically) compared (com ared) with their ancestors (theirancestors).

He does not see the mummers and the wassailers;
he does not hear the voice of ; he scarcely (scracely) listens even
to the song of Canterbury pilgrims. For The English
past as saw it, served only to show up the material
change--the change that had come over houses, furniture (furnt iture)
clothing. There was no English literature to show up the
change (chnage) in the mind. the English songs were [illeg.] Anons song at the back door was as
difficult for (cfor) him to spell as for us. But the old
English (Eglish) songs were more painful. for they reminded him of
his lack of intellectual ancestry (ancstry). His intellectual pedigree
only reached back to , to to .
In order to have ancestors (anscetors) by way of the mind he must cross
the his ancestors by way of the mind are the
Greeks and Romans. His page is burdened (burdneed) with these proofs
ofgood breeding--- ; ; , --he quotes them to prove his
nobility of mind as we to prove ours quote the
Elizabethans. The mummers and the wassailers,
the actors who were actingwho staged their crude dramas in the churchyard (churchayrd)
or in the market place hxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
were sxmxmx He turns from the present to the past;
he ignores the actors (acors) who were acting their crude dramas (daramas)
now in the market place. Yxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx

The historians (histroians) work from the outer to the inner;
from the house they infer the tenant of the house. It is the
house they uncover; the chairs, the tables, the bills, the
close stools (stolls), the spinning wheels, the tapestry.
It is as if we were bidden to infer from a tweed suit,
six hats, a fox terrier, and a silver knobbed (knovved) walking stick
the life and works of a novelist called .
Save for Chaucer (Vhaucer) and Lydgate and the voice of Anon singing
at the back door the English might be a dumb race; a race
of merchants, soldiers (s ldiers), priests (preists) and builders who left behind (nehind)
them stone houses, cultivated fields and many churches and
cathedrals. ; but no words. The great house is silent.
Only the furniture remains, stiff and ornate, fantastic and
uncushioned.

At for instance (instnace)
sat at her table writing (rwiting) to . Her letters (lettres) —compare them with might have
been (veen) sermons from the pulpit (pulpi;t); or state documents (dosuments), intricate (intrcaite)
involved (inlvoved) and evasive. She is a counsellor admonishing a sub
ordinate; she (sShe) is aware (awrae) only of the wickedness of (fof) men,
the dangers and deceits (decits) of the world; and the awfuless of
God. Greek and Latin come to her pen as easily as English ( nglish).
If she has to descend to the actual object--a basket of
strawberries--it is with circumlocutions (cirumlocuitions) and dark
insinuations (insiutaions). "I have sent them by the boy of my kitchen,
a shrewd witted boy and prettily catechized (catchized) but yet an un
toward crafty (rcrafty) boy...." She xxxxxx exhorts (ex horts):
"God keep us sound in faith the faith and send us health (h lth)
and a care to please God above all." She admonishes:
"Be not speedy of speech, nor talk suddenly, but where

discretion (disctreion) requireth, and that soberly then...."
Let not Lawson that fox, be acquainted (acqainted) with my letters...."
So the (Lthe) , mother to the poet Earl
writes:

Fear of God, fear of man, hate, agony, passion, surround
them with the walls of a dungeon. There is no gaiety,
no (nu) freedom no familiarity (familairity) in the world the live in. Only in
extremity, of hate, of fear, do urges them to pick up the pen
The sound of the bible is in their ears, it is (Itis) a garment only
to be worn when the mind is in the right attitude. And the
garment may of course conceal a Lady Ann who is merry and
gay; it may conceal a Duchess who is sensitive (snesitove), amorous
and sensual; we cannot tell. Anybody may live on the other
side of that wall of formal language. Using the prose of
the Bible when they write prose the Elizabethans are unknown
to us. They can say nothing simple, subtle, or little.
Bright contrasted colours meet on their (ther) faces; carnation
and snow; ebony and gold. In their portraits, the young mens
bodies are sewn into padded doublets; school boys faces
are raised above starched (strached) ruffs; and young women serve only
to support (supp rt) heavy quilted ( uilted) dresses stuck about with
huge xxxx pearls.
